p.italic: We isolate two limitations of the existing literature on representation and then move toward some important remedies. The first limitation is that typical representation studies assess the extent to which policymakers’ issue positions correspond to those of the public, but do not investigate whether the issue priorities of policymakers correspond to those of the public. The second limitation is that existing studies do not consider the full policymaking process, from agenda setting to enactment. Using data provided by the Policy Agendas and Congressional Bills Projects, we investigate how well the public's policy priorities have been represented in national policymaking over a 47-year time period. We first assess public concern about 18 major issues using Most Important Problem data (1956–2002) and then correlate these concerns with changing issue attention across 10 policymaking channels that are ordered by differences in institutional friction. We find much closer correspondence where friction is low.

app.label: Appendix
app.title: A Weighted Euclidean Distance Model of Representation
app.p: Underlying positional studies of representation is an implicit model that is incomplete, because it assumes an unweighted Euclidian distance function characterizes the policy spaces of mass publics and of actual government action. We argue that a weighted Euclidian metric is actually appropriate, since it incorporates policy priorities as well as policy distances.

First we look at the simple unweighted model. Let Ak be the agreement between a government policy activity and the collective preferences of the public for a policy. This agreement corresponds to the inverse of the distance between the policy activity and the collective preference. 10 For two policy dimensions of equal weight, this distance is calculated as follows (where the subscript p denotes the government policy position, the subscript c denotes the collective position of the public, and the numerical subscripts refer to the two policy issues):

If we adopt the standard assumption of spatial modeling approaches that the two issues are uncorrelated, 11 we can reduce this to the standard Euclidean distance model where agreement is a simple function of the actors’ positions on the two issues:
A more general model of representation that incorporates priorities, in contrast, modifies this equation to:

Where agreement is a function of three distinct elements:
1)
the positions of the public and government on the two issues;
2)
the weights the public assigns to each issue dimension;
3)
the correlation between these two issue dimensions.
Y is an (n X 1) vector of differences between the spatial location of the public's policy preference and the government's policy activity.

P is a symmetric (n x n) matrix of weights assigned to each issue dimension by the public, what we term the priorities matrix. The on-diagonal elements are the issue weights, and the off-diagonal elements are the correlations between each pair of weights.

We are not in a position at present to estimate this full model, since that would require data on positions and priorities simultaneously. Nevertheless this model clarifies where future empirical research might be directed to advance representational studies that incorporate priorities as well as positions.
